title: Monday, 22nd August, 2016

11:06 am
PM

Economic uncertainty has shot higher since the vote
Direct measures likely overstate the hit to growth
But the initial uncertainty shock will take time to ripple through the economic data

PM

The dog that hasn’t barked since the Brexit vote is strain in financial markets that could have amplified the initial shock. Nevertheless, early survey indicators point to a sizable near term impact on UK growth. The composite measure of economic uncertainty we derived back in February has risen significantly, correctly signaling a drop in the July PMI surveys. Owing to its current composition, this measure almost certainty overstates of the scale of the hit to demand (Figure 1). Nevertheless, uncertainty is set to remain high for some time—and the full impact of this on growth will take time to pass. Even if the UK manages to avoid a recession, as some recent activity indicators have hinted at, the data are likely to remain weak for at least the next few months. And this is before considering the broader structural economic damage from the Brexit vote that will show up more slowly through time.

PM

Uncertainty has risen sharply
The uncertainty indicator we derived prior to the referendum was based on work conducted by the BoE. The indicator includes seven measures of uncertainty (Table 1). Although some correlate with GDP better than others, we used a principal component analysis to aggregate them. The resulting composite has a 0.73 correlation with quarterly GDP growth, and a 0.82 correlation with domestic demand—better than any of its component parts. Prior to the EU referendum, the rise in uncertainty was already comparable to that seen ahead of the Scottish vote on independence. Following the vote to leave the EU, we initially expected this measure of uncertainty to rise by as much seen following the September 11 terrorist attacks or the UK’s ERM exit in 1992—i.e. enough to slow the economy to a crawl. Since the vote, however, this measure of uncertainty has jumped 4-5 standard deviations from its mean—as much as seen during the Lehman failure. Nobody believes things are that bad now, given the more supportive global and financial backdrop. Nevertheless, the uncertainty measure likely contains information that will be helpful for tracking the demand hit.

11:16 am
BE

Via their weekly FX wrap.

BE

Since the FOMC meeting at the end of July, the US dollar has been
retracing the gains made in the immediate aftermath of the Brexit
announcement. The weak US GDP growth in H1 2016 supported the
Federal Reserve’s stance, but it will not be possible to maintain the
monetary status quo if the economy continues to create more than
200,000 jobs each month. In this respect, the market will listen attentively to
the speech that will be given next Friday by Janet Yellen at the Jackson
Hole Symposium. Despite the more accommodating monetary policies
adopted by other leading central banks (Band of England, Bank of Japan,
Reserve Bank of New Zealand, etc.), the greenback will react mainly to
expectations concerning the Federal Reserve’s own monetary policy. If the
Fed Chair remains dovish, the US dollar will continue to fritter away. If the
tone is more hawkish, with Janet Yellen hinting at the need to normalise
monetary policy, then the US dollar could strengthen slightly.

BE

With the ECB sitting on the fence and the dollar weakening, this influenced
the EUR/USD. In the short term, however, the pair could nonetheless correct
towards 1.11 in the face of a firmer greenback. Over the medium term, the
announcement of a QE extension by the central bank should weigh on the
euro. While sterling rebounded on news of stronger-than-expected retail
sales, the underlying trend remains negative for the British currency given
the still very significant economic uncertainties. The Japanese yen
appreciated in the face of a weaker US dollar, also because markets were
disappointed by the underwhelming reaction of the political and monetary
authorities. With political risks set to rear their head in Europe and the US
(presidential election), safe haven currencies like the yen and Swiss franc
should extend their rise in coming months.

11:17 am
BE

Against the backdrop of a rise in commodity prices (crude as well as metals)
and a weaker US dollar, commodity currencies rebounded over the summer,
too much so for the RBNZ, which cut its rates at the start of August. In the
near term, these currencies can be expected to remain upbeat.

BE

he prevailing environment (rise in commodity prices, weaker US dollar and
decline in US long rates) was particularly favourable over the summer to
emerging currencies, which were also bolstered by a resumption of capital
inflows and by an improvement in their fundamentals (notably current
account deficits and inflation). CEEMEA currencies (notably the ZAR and
PLN) and Latam currencies (BRL and CLP) have appreciated most since the
Brexit announcement.

BE

Which tapers into the JPM stuff you started the show with, then abandoned due to issues.

11:26 am
BE

Barclays are buying WillHill.

BE

We reinstate our estimates, PT and rating for William Hill. Our rating remains
Overweight, our PT increases 3% to 340p and we update our estimates (FY16-18E EPS
increase 2%/9%/7%). While WMH is in transition and execution risks are elevated, as we
outlined in our note ‘One for the Contrarians’ (7/6/16), William Hill is cheap (FY17 P/E
12.3x, 4% dividend yield), and there are potential positive catalysts in H2 (announcements
around costs savings in retail and online and we hope news on a new CEO). That said, we
continue to prefer Paddy Power Betfair given its superior growth, strong balance sheet
and strategic optionality.

BE

Changes to estimates: WMH has stated that it expects FY16 EBITA to be towards the top
its £260-280m guidance. We forecast £275m (previously £265m): the main improvement
coming from stronger Retail Gross Win Margins (buoyed by the European
Championships) and higher-than-expected machine growth. All changes to our forecasts
are on Page 3. Our FY16-18 EBITA increase 4%/4%/3% and EPS increase 2%/9% /7%.

11:26 am
BE

Unknowns remain: There is much left to do to turnaround the Online division. We have
been encouraged by the early progress under the new leadership of Crispin Nieboer, but it
is early days. At the Q3 results, we hope for more detail: i)on cost savings from
reorganizing the Retail division; ii) news of cost efficiencies in the Online division; and iii)
news regarding a new CEO. We think all three issues may be a positive catalyst in H2,
albeit we think some of the cost savings will be reinvested for growth.

BE

Price target 340p: We leave our valuation methodology unchanged. We use the average
of our DCF (370p) and EV/EBITDA SOTP (310p) to generate our 340p PT. For the sum of
the parts, we continue to apply a 12.5x EV/EBITDA multiple to the Online divisions and a
7x multiple to the Retail division. At our PT, WMH would trade on CY17 a P/E of 13x,
which is a material discount to PPB, which trades on 22x reflecting PPB’s stronger growth,
balance sheet and stronger historical track record of beating expectations. Our upside
case implies 42% upside and our downside case implies 41% downside. We wrote
extensively on the downside risks should the UK slip into a mild-recession in 2017 in our
note ‘Cyclical risk vs. Structural Growth’ (8/7/16).

BE

Some reheat-type mentions in the weekend press about CVC being a possible bidder for William Hill, incidentally.

11:30 am
BE

Airline acquisition of questionable strategic sense for AerCap: AerCap,
as the largest global lessor having acquired ILFC in 2014, is a well-oiled
aircraft leasing and trading machine. At June AerCap had a current owned
and managed fleet of 1,637 including 435 on order (including 1,247
narrowbodies in total) which compared to EZJ's owned fleet of 184 A320-
family units at March. Acquiring an airline would represent a major
divergence in strategy for questionable benefits to the lessor. We also note
AerCap trades on 0.88x 2017E book value whereas easyJet trades on a P/B
ex-goodwill of 2.5x, suggesting acquiring an interest in EZJ as an asset-play
may be unattractive to it despite the fact that EZJ likely enjoys market-
leading aircraft purchase discounts (we expect easyJet's economic price to
book value to be nearer 1x, marking its own fleet to market and AerCap has
publicly confirmed it sees more value in buying back its own stock than
purchasing aircraft at current market values). Further, AerCap is a Dutch/Irish
company which is technically free to invest in EZJ today but with Brexit, any
potential investment in EZJ will be subject to updated foreign ownership
restrictions for UK airlines.

BE

That's Neil Glynn, who knows EasyJet better than anyone.

PM

Why would this leasing business possibly want to buy a low cost carrier?

(@Otter: I think I'm right in saying that only Liberum covers it, and they haven't.)

BE

Since we're here, and since it's published today, have Davy pushing Ryanair.

11:36 am
BE

The European airline sector has lost 20% of its value by market
cap in the last two months, driven by 16% earnings
downgrades. This report reviews key recent trends across the
sector and the near-term outlook into the end of the year. We
think Ryanair stands out as the most compelling investment
case at current share price levels, screening well on structural
growth, defensiveness and valuation metrics. We expect
greater granularity on ancillaries to be a catalyst for the
remainder of the year. We also still see good long-term value in
IAG, but the stock lacks positive catalysts in the very short term.

BE

LCCs requiring greater pricing stimulation to maintain volumes

The low-cost space continues to see strong volume growth (11% in Q2 and July) and
load factor improvement (+1.0pp in Q2, +0.8pp in July), but it now requires the greatest
degree of pricing stimulation since Q1 2014 (unit revenue was down 6% constant
currency on average in Q2). We see peak (Q3) summer pricing continuing to be weak but
on an improving trajectory (-4% on average). Into calendar H2, Wizz Air’s FY pricing
guidance looks demanding, with something of a pricing recovery required despite
increasing overlap with Ryanair. Ryanair carries the best cost momentum into the second
half, providing support to FY guidance against soft demand conditions.

BE

Pricing volatility means legacies likely to trim winter capacity

Although the legacies see varying trends on premium versus corporate demand and by
route, the common theme is weaker pricing. Further, our H2 assumptions imply that
year-on-year pricing declines will be at least the same if not worse than H1 (3pp and 5pp
worse at Lufthansa and Air France-KLM respectively). However, incremental cost
improvements are evident at all three, while capacity remains under review for winter,
particularly at British Airways.

11:37 am
BE

Ryanair best positioned; IAG still ‘Outperform’, Air France-KLM to
‘Neutral’

Reflecting its strong relative cost and revenue trends, and near-term catalysts, Ryanair is
our top pick in the space. Our €14 price target is based on 13x P/E and 7.5x EV/EBITDAR.
We think that IAG’s 13% free cash flow yield and 5% dividend yield provide a good
entry point. We expect the company to retain its long-term targets at its November
capital markets day. Our price target remains at £4.6. We reduce our price targets for
Lufthansa to €11, Air France-KLM to €5.5, easyJet to £11 and Wizz Air to €18.0. We also
move our rating on Air France-KLM from ‘Outperform’ to ‘Neutral’. Of our ‘Neutral’
recommendations, we note that easyJet has the most to gain in FY2017 should external
disruptions (ATC strikes, terrorist events) ease.

Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYA:LSE): Last: 12.12, up 0.12 (+1.00%), High: 12.16, Low: 11.90, Volume: 297.16k

Pfizer is nearing a deal worth about $14bn to acquire California biotechnology company Medivation, beating a handful of its biggest rivals to win the auction for the sought-after cancer drugmaker.

People close to the talks said a deal between Pfizer, the world’s second-largest drugmaker, and Medivation could be announced as early as Monday, though they cautioned that the two sides were in the process of finalising their agreement.

BE

11:41 am

hmm

BE

Such as around Illumina, which you can find on the archive yourself.

BE

(@roddy1234: I watched that on Saturday! Odd coincidence.)

11:43 am
BE

Anyway, worry is that Pfizer's overpaying.

BE

Here's RBC.

BE

1) PRICE: We have a very difficult time getting to the ~$80/share price that
Pfizer (PFE Not Covered) is reported to be paying based on reasonable
modeling assumptions for the company. We remind investors that Xtandi
is shared with Astellas. Also, media reports point to an all-cash transaction,
which is both surprising, given the risk involved in second asset talazoparib
and a credit to MDVN's management, which may manage to sell this asset,
without any or much of a CVR (if that indeed ends up being the case),
with talazoparib Phase III data around the corner. The reference in our title
points to Pfizer's first love affair with Medivation, when it spent $225M for
Alzheimer's compound Dimebon in 2008: Dimebon failed 19 months later.
However, that cash provided the R&D fuel for Xtandi. And Medivation
remained one of the most shareholder-friendly companies, rarely raising
equity. Both the first PFE transaction and the subsequent remarkably non-
dilutive trajectory are a credit to the efforts of MDVN CEO David Hung.

11:44 am
BE

2) PROCESS: Even though we don't have visibility to how formalized the
bidding process was, this appeared to be a fairly structured auction. There
had been prior reports for bids being due in mid-August. If accurate, all
this is consistent with last night's news that PFE came out as the auction's
winner. So, even though it's not over until (OK, you know where this
is going), we see it as very unlikely (but not impossible) that another
company will come up with a higher bid.

BE

So, you're telling me there's a chance? We see a 15%-20% chance of
a higher bid. Sanofi is, of course, the company investors are wondering
about. Perhaps they may want to avoid the "embarrassment" of losing
an auction. On the other hand, we could see a SNY press release talking
about "discipline". So, given the already very high price being discussed,
the difficult public relationship between MDVN and SNY (not that anything
couldn't be fixed by an extra $2-$4/share), and the fact that this was a
fairly structured process, we see a higher bid as very unlikely, but not
impossible, and we leave an outside chance that a higher offer comes in at
$82-$84. Most likely outcome: a PR announcing the transaction this week.

BE

It's interesting -- in the context of recent rumours we've harped on about quite a lot already -- that the auction's concluding before the PARP inhibitor data is pubbed.

11:45 am
BE

But we're not here to talk about PARP inhibitor data, because .......

BE

*PFIZER TO BUY MEDIVATION FOR $81.50 A SHARE IN CASH

BE

There. On the tape.

11:46 am
undefined
PM

David has pinged over Hartnett

PM

150 stocks to benefit from fiscal stimulus globally

11:47 am
PM

Let me share a bit

PM

The Policy Flip from Monetary to Fiscal Stimulus Electorates are increasingly voting for policies to address wage deflation, immigration &
inequality. The capitalist, monetarist, globalist consensus of recent decades is now
under threat and policies that are more socialist, Keynesian, and protectionist are being
promised. We have argued over the past year that investors must anticipate this “policy
flip” from monetary to fiscal stimulus by shifting from Wall Street to Main Street plays.

PM

Fiscal stimulus is a Transforming World theme BofAML's Global Economics team believe that after several years of government belttightening,
fiscal stances around the world have already become more supportive of
growth and that the prospects for additional fiscal stimulus have improved in a number
of countries. Our macro team notes that it has never been cheaper for governments to
fund investments in transportation and information infrastructure or training and
education programs.

11:47 am
PM

The “Keynesian Put” The new threat of fiscal stimulus should help underpin asset prices, in our view. And as
policy shifts from the exclusive and extensive use of monetary policy in recent years to
create growth, to a more strategic & balanced mix of fiscal and monetary policy, we
believe asset allocators should rebalance portfolios away from the “QE winners” toward
assets and sectors that should benefit from more fiscal largesse such as companies with
exposure to Main Street, infrastructure, defense, and real assets (Table 1).

PM

Let me get table 1

PM

11:48 am
PM

This report lists 150 global stocks most leveraged to potential fiscal stimulus as
identified by our global equity analysts. It is a companion to BofAML's fiscal spending
primer. Infrastructure & construction companies dominate, comprising 61% of the list;
15% of the likely beneficiaries are in technology, networking, and cybersecurity. Energy,
defense, and healthcare companies represent 12% of the other fiscal beneficiaries.

PM

BE

Sports Direct is paying some of its takings from website customers outside the UK to a little-known delivery broker owned by the older brother of its billionaire founder Mike Ashley, the Financial Times has found.

The FTSE 250-listed retailer, which is Britain’s biggest sportswear chain and operates local-language websites serving 33 other countries, has not disclosed the arrangement in its published accounts.

It adds to the list of transactions between Sports Direct and personal connections of its billionaire founder. In January it emerged that Mr Ashley had put his daughter’s boyfriend, a 26-year-old former nightclub promoter, in charge of Sports Direct’s property team via a consultancy contract that could see him paid millions of pounds.

Barlin Delivery is owned by John Ashley and has its registered office in a detached house in a Cleethorpes cul-de-sac, a small seaside resort on the Humber estuary in Lincolnshire. The company receives a share of the revenue from Sports Direct’s website orders that are dispatched overseas.

BE

Now, we'd like to comment on this ... but having all last week watched the tricky process of getting it into the paper, I'd rather not.

12:01 pm
BE

Quick line from Jefferies.

BE

VR's focus on Russian construction and North American O&G
markets pose a double-whammy of challenges. While total Russian steel demand fell 2% YoY
in H1, rebar fell a more notable 14%. EVR has maintained strong market share despite rising
competition, but the best hope may come from an increased focus on export markets as
EVR recently received certification for rebar sales into European markets (additional benefit
from share gains as EU imports of Chinese/Belarusian steel are curtailed by duties). In NA,
EVR's exposure to the OCTG and LDP markets will remain hindered by poor O&G spend,
though an expected end of destocking may gradually moderate headwinds into 2017.

BE

Reported Net Debt of $5.3b increased 4% from YE15 and was 10% above JEFe, leaving
Net Debt/LTM EBITDA at a risky 4.9x vs 3.7x at YE15. While EVR has made progress extending debt maturities with steps taken in H1 cutting 2016-17 maturities by 60%, this brought higher interest rates attributed to new RUB-denominated bonds.
